ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Helped me learn about the broad concerns in the history of money through the story of different periods -particularly in regards to coins and bills.
Learned about how money came to be and changed over time, but also came to learn about what money represented socially and culturally.
I learned about the conceptual evolution of money starting from its roots as a commodity down to its current formation as a fiat currency. Yet, all the nuance in between did not go to waste.
great survey course about the history of money from roman coinage to crypto
I gained experience reading and analyzing primary sources.
I learned about the history of money
I learnt a lot about how money developed and the impact of various historical events on its development. I can say that I thoroughly understand the way money is today due to its historical context.
Learned about how money has evolved over human history with focus on ancient, early European and early US money.
I was able to learn in detail how modern currency came to be, and all the nuances that lie behind the term of "money"

Throughout this course, I learned how the history of money was very important to the modern systems of money. Some skills I learned was to understand how money was developed throughout ways such as goldsmith notes.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great class if you are interested in money at all -- was a little disorganized, but that was Yale's fault for not assigning a TA earlier

Well researched and structured, could benefit from discussing the concept of money (as studied in some of the readings) in class -for example the role of the ledger. Give more time to private monies and digital currencies.

I thought the content was very interesting and Professor Ogle clearly cared about the class. I think I would have liked more readings that were secondary source based and presenting arguments from various scholars. For example, my favorite reading was The Currency of Politics and would have loved reading more similar works.
Strengths: The way the professor presented the narrative behind all the different arguments. She helped extract the social changes that influenced the physical and effective changes in money.
awesome course, no weaknesses

Strengths: The course subject matter is very interesting and offers a historical dimension to monetary questions typically confined to economics. Moreover, Professor Ogle is a good lecturer with an extensive knowledge of the subject matter. 

Weaknesses: Given the length of time this course covers, it can often feel like you are jumping from moment to moment without gaining a solid background in any specific period or historical process. The end of the course is especially compressed, with the entirety Gold Standard and Bretton Woods systems covered in only two lectures. Additionally, primary sources are concentrated in the Financial Revolution modules, and you don't really encounter them elsewhere. Writing assignments are also few and far between, which is helpful for managing workloads but hurts you if you're looking to improve your historical writing.
Posting lecture slides before class would help since I like to write notes on the slides

You learn a lot of very interesting material! However, it was sometimes slightly disorganized and difficult to know exactly when things were due and what we had to write - Professor Ogle is very accommodating though, and does a fantastic job of clarifying if you ask.
Strengths: super light workload, easy grading and the material was ~pretty interesting~. Weakness: the class was super unorganized.

Strength: Very structured approach to the history of money and very easy to understand
Weaknesses: Would be nicer to receive more feedback on the midterm and sections to be more engaging.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Interesting if you really care about the topic.

I would. Money is as pervasive as ever in our world and understanding its origins and the central themes surrounding money throughout history can provide useful context for understanding its current state.
Absolutely, money is such an influence on behavior. Why not learn about where it comes from and how it got here.
absolutely, you learn so much and Ogle is a great teacher
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in monetary policy/politics or questions of the economy more broadly.
Yes this class is very interesting and fun to learn about, the assignments were very creative and somewhat challenging

The material is often fascinating, the readings are short but relevant and interesting, and Professor Ogle is a genuine expert in the subject. The workload is completely manageable however - it could be a great, but interesting, 5th class if needed. Definitely take the course!
Easy history credit, would probably recommend but didn't get a ton out of the class.

Yes, I initially took this class to fulfill my humanities requirement but was surprised at how interesting and fun this class was. I am an economics major and was fascinated to find parallels between historical and contemporary events. I would highly recommend this class.

Yes I would recommend this course other students because it was very informative and interesting. It really helped me understand how we transitioned from different money systems and the current paper money we use today.
